search_result.text:
New York (CNN Business) A version of this article first appeared in the "Reliable Sources" newsletter. You can sign up for free right here.

Two newspapers owned by Gannett, one in Indiana and one in Ohio, have humanized the new American reality about abortion now that Roe v. Wade has been reversed. And in doing so, they have highlighted the inhumanity of some partisan punditry.

On July 1, the Indianapolis Star reported that a 10-year-old girl in Ohio was pregnant, and because "the Buckeye state had outlawed any abortion after six weeks," the girl was brought to Indiana for an abortion. The source was Dr. Caitlin Bernard, an obstetrician-gynecologist in Indianapolis, who said she had conferred with a child abuse doctor in Ohio.

No further details about the girl or the alleged rapist were obtainable, even though some news outlets tried. In recent days, after President Biden cited the news report and denounced Ohio's abortion ban, many conservative media outlets and Republican office-holders poured skepticism on the case, and some personalities flatly said they did not believe the 10-year-old existed. Rep. Jim Jordan tweeted: "Another lie. Anyone surprised?"

You know what's coming next. On Wednesday, the Columbus Dispatch reported that a man has been charged in the case. Police say Gerson Fuentes, 27, "confessed to raping the child on at least two occasions."

None of the media outlets that sowed doubt about the case were in court for the arraignment. Hardly any of them were even in the state. The Dispatch's Bethany Bruner said she was the "only reporter in the courtroom" when it happened. "This confirms that the case exists," she wrote on Twitter, sharing the link to her story.

Bruner said the Dispatch relied on public records to track down Fuentes. It's "fitting," Washington Post media critic Erik Wemple said , "that perhaps the biggest abortion story since the SCOTUS overturning of Roe v. Wade stems from regional/local newspapers, because that's where the reporting on this issue will be playing out for months and years. A brand-new test for a hollowed-out American media sector."

The doubters and deniers

Right-wing skepticism about the case bubbled up on social media last week and boiled over after Washington Post fact-checker Glenn Kessler wrote abou t the difficulty in confirming Bernard's account. On Monday Fox's Jesse Watters hosted Ohio's Republican A.G. Dave Yost, who said there was "not a whisper" of any evidence that such a crime occurred. Up until Wednesday morning, "Yost was on a media tour casting doubt on the veracity of the story," and criticizing the Indianapolis Star, Vice's Paul Blest wrote . Segments on Fox also heaped suspicion on the Star's story. The WSJ's editorial board called it an "unlikely story from a biased source that neatly fits the progressive narrative but can't be confirmed," adding, "PJ Media's Megan Fox was first to point this out."

Once the Dispatch reported on the suspect's arrest, Fox came up with other reasons to blast the media , and Watters credited his show with putting on "the pressure" to find the suspect, adding, "we are glad that justice is being served." He plastered Bernard's photo on screen and accused her of participating in a coverup. Then his guest attacked the Indy Star and its "abortionist movement." One hour later, Tucker Carlson strongly implied that the identity of the suspect was shrouded in secrecy because, in Carlson's words, "apparently the rapist was an illegal alien." The suspect's immigration status is now the focus of right-wing media coverage.

There are so many untold stories

For more on this awful episode, check out NPR's new report by David Folkenflik and Sarah McCammon. They wrote that it "illustrates the high stakes of both the new legal landscape on abortion and of reporting in an age of deep political polarization and mistrust of major news outlets."

The Dispatch is ready. Wednesday's story by Bruner and her colleagues Monroe Trombly and Tony Cook not only contains critical details from the courtroom, it includes the broader context that everyone on every side of the reproductive rights debate needs to face. Like this: "An analysis of Columbus police reports filed since May 9 found 50 reports of rape or sexual abuse involving girls 15 years or younger."

That's a report almost every single day, in just one metro area, and certainly a partial count -- underscoring a vast number of untold stories. The Dispatch story also notes that "the ability of Ohio residents to seek abortion services in Indiana could soon be curtailed," since Republican lawmakers in the state are expected to enact new restrictions later this summer.

A 10 year old is being treated "as a political chess piece"

Editorial writers and TV talking heads will move on tomorrow, but the people at the center of this case will be changed forever.

Washington Post columnist Alyssa Rosenberg made a really important point here : "Even if the girl in Ohio remains anonymous — and the national media attention, the arrest of her alleged rapist and his naming in the press make that seem unlikely — she will someday know that her 10-year-old self was treated not as a person the whole nation had an interest in protecting, but as a political chess piece." Shame on the nation, she says, "that put a 10-year-old in the worst possible circumstances through an unnecessary ordeal, and then argued about whether she was a hoax."

Correction: Sarah McCammon's name was misspelled in a previous version of this story.

search_result.title: A stunning moment in American history decades in the making will ...
search_result.text:
The Supreme Court's overturning of a woman's right to an abortion on Friday was a legal, political and societal thunderbolt that merits the overused term "historic" because it will change life in multiple ways, many still unknown.

But while shocking, especially since it goes against majority public opinion on the issue, it was not a surprise. The ruling was the result of a staggeringly successful generational quest by the conservative movement at all political levels, from grassroots social and religious activists through the founding leaders of a right-wing legal establishment to successive Republican presidents.

Democrats working through phases of disbelief, fury and pain on Friday vowed to fight back. But their mission, like that of their conservative vanquishers, could last decades or even longer in pursuit of a distant goal.

"Make no mistake: This decision is the culmination of a deliberate effort over decades to upset the balance of our law. It's a realization of an extreme ideology and a tragic error by the Supreme Court," President Joe Biden said . But he added: "This is not over."

Another top Democrat, Sen. Elizabeth Warren of Massachusetts, said she was "spitting mad."

"We've got tools. We're going to use them in November. We're going to make sure that we elect enough people who believe in democracy that we can pass Roe v. Wade and make it the law of the land again," she told CNN. "Only this time, we'll do it by statute and enforce it."

JUST WATCHED 'I'm spitting mad': Elizabeth Warren shares anger over ruling in interview Replay More Videos ... MUST WATCH 'I'm spitting mad': Elizabeth Warren shares anger over ruling in interview 03:52

But the generational nature of the struggle to come means it's not likely to be septuagenarians like Biden and Warren who win it.

The prospects of an immediate political riposte are also unlikely, given the Democrats' current political woes. If the outpouring of liberal emotion is to coalesce into a counter-movement to restore abortion rights, it will require the same level of multi-decade dedication shown by conservatives. It will call for a network of political groups all pushing in the same direction and for national politicians with the talent to turn out voters on the issue using their time in office to build a competing legal and political structure effective at pressing change. And it will have to begin as a rearguard action after a stunning defeat as multiple conservative states pass or implement flash laws to outlaw abortion for millions of women.

Abortion is a deeply personal issue for many Americans that involves choices about when life begins and an individual's rights to make a decision about their own body. It becomes a sensitive and divisive political issue when it comes to the questions of whether and how government can dictate these moral and legal questions and what the Constitution permits.

JUST WATCHED CNN commentator challenged on her religion and abortion stance. See her response Replay More Videos ... MUST WATCH CNN commentator challenged on her religion and abortion stance. See her response 06:32

So just as liberals may now be newly fired up, the anti-abortion movement will not rest. Some activists are already striving to elect a Republican-led Congress and president who would outlaw abortion not just in conservative states but also in the blue ones that immediately vowed Friday to protect a woman's right to choose. And while Biden can carp about Republican extremists and liberals complain about Republican presidents failing to win the popular vote, the conservative movement looks just as likely to mobilize to use the US political system to preserve its win as Democrats are to try to overturn it.

Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell, who did as much as any Republican leader to transform the Supreme Court, praised the years of conservative campaigning that had led to Friday's decision.

"Millions of Americans have spent half a century praying, marching and working toward today's historic victories for the rule of law and for innocent life. I have been proud to stand with them throughout our long journey and I share their joy today," the Kentucky Republican said.

Arkansas Republican Gov. Asa Hutchinson tweeted: "... we are able now to protect life."

A cascade of consequences

Friday's victory was so total for conservatives and will be so difficult for Democrats to reverse not only because of its immediate legal consequence, but also because of the cascade of effects it will unleash, some not even connected to abortion.

Anti-abortion activists are celebrating not just potentially millions of future pregnancies that will go to term, but a profound turn in the country's policies as well, which will change what it means to live in America for men as well as women.

But at the same time, tens of millions of women went to bed Friday evening with one fewer constitutional right than they had woken up with. As conservative states begin to outlaw abortion entirely, the ledger of Americans' rights will depend on where they live or conceive. For apparently the first time in the country's historic march, the Supreme Court has taken away a previously enshrined constitutional right. The starkly literal reading of the Constitution by the court's conservative majority in this case -- as well as in other judicial haymakers on guns and religion this week -- beckons an era of societal upheaval.

If one constitutional right can be wiped out, why not others? Already, and despite the assurances of several of the court's conservatives, same-sex marriage, contraception and even in vitro fertilization treatments are beginning to look more vulnerable.

This week's rulings on abortion and guns have cemented the court's new conservative majority as a staggeringly powerful force in American life -- one with the audacity to make far-reaching change. Because this upheaval comes from a bench of deeply religious conservatives, it is certain to trigger confrontations with more secular, diverse sectors of society. These factors, and the court's recent opinions conflicting with majority public opinion, mean that America's vicious ideological divide is all but certain to deepen. But the justices are insulated from politics by lifetime appointments.

JUST WATCHED 'It's so startling': Joan Biskupic reacts to Roe v Wade overturn Replay More Videos ... MUST WATCH 'It's so startling': Joan Biskupic reacts to Roe v Wade overturn 00:50

A triumph for Trump and McConnell

If it wasn't the case already, Friday solidified the presidency of Donald Trump, who helped tip the court to the right, as one of deep, historic consequence. It validated the marriage of convenience between the ethically challenged former President and evangelicals and social conservatives, which was rooted in the promise that he would nominate anti-abortion justices.

And it confirms McConnell, whose contentious maneuverings unlocked the path to the conservative majority, as one of the most meaningful political figures of all time. Trump and McConnell's work -- in the shape of three comparatively young justices -- will be changing the face of America for long after they are gone. The nature of the Senate, which allows Republicans to wield considerable power despite representing far fewer people in more rural states, will make it difficult for Democrats to transform majority opinion into a law codifying Roe v. Wade.

JUST WATCHED Roe v. Wade is overturned. How does this affect you? Replay More Videos ... MUST WATCH Roe v. Wade is overturned. How does this affect you? 02:02

In the short term, Friday's decision could play into the midterm elections in November, which House Speaker Nancy Pelosi vowed to turn on the abortion decision. But with voters hammered by high inflation and record gasoline prices, they may be focused on more pressing economic concerns -- especially in the places where Democrats need to make gains in order to hold on to their narrow majorities.

The new reality on abortion is certain to add even more intensity to the 2024 presidential campaign with Democrats facing the possibility of a Republican monopoly on power.

And as they were in the pandemic, governors and state legislators will become vital players on a fearsomely divisive national issue, as some hurriedly pass laws to outlaw the right to end a pregnancy and others fight to preserve it. There are likely to be disputes over the power of states to stop residents seeking abortions from traveling to states where the procedure is still allowed.

Big business is about to be embroiled in a fight over the rights of female employees that could affect the locations of headquarters and will require firms to consider how to deal with new health care conundrums. The conservative majority suggested in its opinion that sending abortion back to the states to decide will let democracy work it out. But nothing in the polarized state of American politics suggests this is anything more than wishful thinking. Abortion is likely to drive an already torn nation further into self-estrangement.

A historic campaign to change America

In many ways, Friday's tumultuous events were the right's answer to an almost as epic summer week seven years ago, when the court seemed to launch a period of liberal ascendency by saving the Affordable Care Act and ruling that same-sex marriage was constitutional. Those heady few days, however, helped spark a backlash that led to Trump's presidency and, ultimately, to this week's momentous opinions.

But the genesis of this moment came long before, beginning to build soon after the 1973 Roe v. Wade decision the court just overturned. It took a web of alliances and interlocking campaigns by religious conservatives, activist groups, fundraisers, grassroots lawmakers, faith leaders, anti-abortion marchers, national political leaders, talk radio hosts, right-wing media figures and Republican presidents over decades to come to fruition. It involved years of confirmations that turned the federal judiciary to the right, then de facto alliances between jurists and conservative politicians in the states to bring cases weakening and eventually ending the federal right to an abortion up through the courts.

And it took Supreme Court nominees misleading Senate confirmation hearings, with a wink and a nod, on their opposition to overturning precedent to create the majority in the marble-pillared Supreme Court chamber that would finish the job.

The movement was especially energized by the conservative renaissance that President Ronald Reagan engineered. As California governor, he had signed a law allowing some exceptions to abortion but changed his views after a long period of soul searching and after spotting an opening to use the issue to electrify the conservative movement. In February 1984, Reagan wrote in his diary about a conversation with a woman in Peoria, Illinois, who had broken with Republicans because of his stance on the issue.

"I made my pitch that there were 2 people's rights involved in abortion — the mother's & the unborn child," Reagan wrote, spelling out a message that fortified the mission even after his death.

The next Republican president, George H.W. Bush, appointed Justice Clarence Thomas, who waited in silence for decades on the bench for his hardline conservative jurisprudence to dominate the court. He published a concurrent opinion on Friday that read like a rallying call for activists and conservative states to challenge other precedents, on same-sex marriage and contraception.

President Bill Clinton kept conservatives at bay for eight years and his nominee, Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg, became an icon for women's rights during her long tenure. But her death in 2020, while Trump was in the White House, opened the way for a solidifying of the 5-4 conservative majority that overturned Roe on Friday.

The next President, George W. Bush, did his bit for an abortion earthquake still 17 years in the future by nominating Justice Samuel Alito, who penned Friday's majority opinion.

The Obama presidency featured then-Majority Leader McConnell's blockade of the President's final nominee, Merrick Garland (now Biden's attorney general), which allowed newly elected Trump to elevate another member of Friday's majority, Justice Neil Gorsuch. And then McConnell reversed his hastily created rule against confirming justices before elections, which he'd used to keep Garland off the court, to install another anti-abortion justice in Amy Coney Barrett days before Trump lost in 2020. Without his efforts, the fifth vote to reverse Roe would not have existed, since Chief Justice John Roberts, while opposing abortion, signaled support for a less radical course.

JUST WATCHED OB-GYN explains the far-reaching effects of Roe ruling Replay More Videos ... MUST WATCH OB-GYN explains the far-reaching effects of Roe ruling 03:34

These are all fateful presidential decisions and congressional battles fought over decades. They are a taste of what Democrats face if they want to reverse Friday's decision and the coming era of conservative jurisprudence. Their long haul will be complicated by the fact that Gorsuch, Barrett and Justice Brett Kavanaugh are only in their 50s and figure to have years of service on the court in which to further solidify Friday's ruling.

For abortion rights activists, meanwhile, the next few presidential elections just got even more critical and will test whether complacency among liberals about the supposed inviolability of the right to end a pregnancy will begin to change.

Almost every Republican campaign, up and down the ballot, has long included a push for ending abortion. The issue was a unifying force in Republican politics as activists drove toward the single, distant goal that was realized on Friday.

Democrats have yet to prove that they have the discipline, organizational capacity or rising political stars to mount a similar fight of their own.

search_result.title: Arizona election updates: More ballot results expected Friday morning
search_result.text:
Arizona Republic

Arizona enters its second day of postelection waiting on Thursday as mail-in ballots dropped off at the polls continued to be counted in elections offices in the state's 15 counties.

Follow Friday election results here.

Arizona voters approved Proposition 208, a bid to raise teacher salaries by increasing taxes on the state's highest earners, according to The Associated Press.

Infowars host and conspiracy theorist Alex Jones joined a protest outside an election center in downtown Phoenix.

President Donald Trump gained ground on Democratic candidate Joe Biden in many areas around the state Thursday night, though Biden still leads.

Elections officials hit back at the Arizona attorney general in letters about Sharpies on Thursday. The issue also went to court on Thursday.

The Trump campaign held a news conference, saying it wasn't suing over the state's vote count ... at least not yet.

Follow along for updates throughout the day from Arizona Republic reporters.

SEE WHO WON: Arizona election results

11 p.m.: Trump draws closer to Biden in Arizona ballot count, but falls off pace needed to win state

President Donald Trump inched closer to former Vice President Joe Biden as results from Thursday's ballot counting were released, but he fell off the pace needed to win Arizona's 11 electoral votes.

Trump won 55.6% of the ballots counted in Maricopa County on Thursday to Biden's 41.7%. It was a great showing, but Trump's challenge is he needs more than 57% of the outstanding votes to win.

Statewide, Trump chipped away 22,000 votes from Biden's lead, closing the gap to 46,667 votes as of 9:30 p.m. Thursday. But unless the next batches of votes show Trump with a higher percentage than what the president managed on Thursday, he will fall short.

— Rob O'Dell

10:45 p.m.: Protest winds down; more results expected 9 a.m. Friday

After some spent more than seven hours protesting in the "free speech zone" set up in the parking lot of a Maricopa County elections office on Thursday, the demonstration wound down by 10:45 p.m. with only a few dozen people left.

Maricopa County officials said earlier in the day that the next round of ballot results could be expected about 9 a.m. Friday.

— Kaila White

10 p.m.: Let's talk about the 2016 Arizona vote count

In 2016, Arizona’s presidential contest hadn’t declared a clear winner by the time the national contest was all but settled in President Donald Trump’s favor.

At the Arizona Republican Party’s 2016 election night watch party, former Arizona Gov. Jane Hull’s son, Michael, shouted into the microphone that Arizona needed to be called for Trump.

The Associated Press didn’t call the race for Trump in Arizona until two days after Election Day, on Nov. 10, 2016.

Until then, it wasn’t clear enough how the state would tilt for the AP to make a call, the news outlet wrote on that date in 2016.

“The Republican president-elect had a solid lead over Hillary Clinton on election night, but a winner wasn't declared because there were so many uncounted votes. The latest batch of returns tabulated Thursday made him the clear winner,” the AP wrote in 2016.

At that time, three states hadn’t been called by the time Trump won: Arizona, Michigan and New Hampshire. But his victories in other states made his national win clear by Nov. 9.

A history of close races and ballot counts of several days before winners are declared by news organizations is somewhat common in Arizona.

The race for U.S. senator in Arizona in 2018 took six days to be called because it was close.

— Rachel Leingang

9:30 p.m.: Website shows uncounted ballot rundown

Hundreds of thousands of ballots still need to be counted statewide.

The Arizona Secretary of State’s Office has a rundown of how many ballots remain in each county posted on its website, which is updated when county elections officials provide information.

Some uncounted ballots need to go through signature verification, which is necessary for mail-in ballots. Others are provisional ballots that elections officials need to assess.

You can follow along to see how many ballots remain uncounted around the state at https://arizona.vote/ballot-progress.html, but be mindful of the time stamp for when the number for each county was last updated.

— Rachel Leingang

9:15 p.m.: Protesters linger outside elections office

Although Alex Jones had been gone for at least half an hour and Maricopa County election officials said the next drop of ballot results would be 9 a.m. Friday, about 100 protesters lingered in the parking lot of the Maricopa County Tabulation and Election Center in downtown Phoenix.

— Chelsea Curtis and Madeline Ackley

8:50 p.m.: Protesters chase away counterprotesters

The mood of the crowd at a protest outside a Maricopa County election center in downtown Phoenix shot up with the arrival of Infowars host and conspiracy theorist Alex Jones.

The crowd entered the road and a group of people began screaming at and following a handful of counterprotesters, one carrying a poster of Trump depicted as a pig.

According to videos posted on social media, a man in head-to-toe camouflage tried to hold back the people yelling at the counterprotesters, telling them, “It’s not worth it,” and another man wearing a Trump flag tied around his neck used the pole holding his American flag to make a barrier. Some began chasing the counterprotesters, yelling “USA” and “Leave the country!”

A man wearing a "Trump 45" jersey threw something at the counterprotesters and then said, "Peaceful time is over." Right-wing social-media personality Mike Cernovich told the man, "Brother, we don't talk like this," in an attempt to calm him down.

Maricopa County Sheriff's Office deputies worked to separate the group and get people out of the road. Jones then seemed to disappear from the scene.

— Madeline Ackley and Chelsea Curtis

8:30 p.m.: Alex Jones gives speech to crowd

Alex Jones climbed on top of something to address the crowd.

“America is fighting for its life and the moment we’re in is as important as 1776 July 4th so I love you and I admire you and I salute you and I appreciate you,” he said to cheers. “The world is watching the example of Arizona, the president is watching the example, you’re not gonna let ‘em steal this.”

"Fascist commies that will be defeated," he said.

— Kaila White

8:20 p.m.: Alex Jones shows up at Phoenix protest outside elections office

The crowd erupted when Infowars host and conspiracy theorist Alex Jones showed up to the protest outside the Maricopa County Tabulation and Election Center in downtown Phoenix.

The crowd of hundreds of people swarmed around him and chanted his name. He took a megaphone and began screaming into it.

He then yelled, “America is united” and “1776!”

— Kaila White

8:20 p.m.: Proposition 208 passes, AP says

Arizona voters approved Proposition 208, a bid to raise teacher salaries by increasing taxes on the state's highest earners, according to The Associated Press.

The measure, also known as the Invest in Education Act, would raise revenue primarily for educator salaries by adding a 3.5% tax surcharge on taxable income over $250,000 for individuals and $500,000 for couples. A small fraction of taxpayers would be affected.

— Lily Altavena

8:15 p.m.: Protester says this was her first time

Thuy Ngo is from Vietnam and she said she left because of its communist government and became a U.S. citizen 20 years ago. She didn’t vote for Trump four years ago but did this time around.

“I’ve seen what he’s done for America,” she said.

Ngo said she supports Trump for economic and religious reasons, as she is anti-abortion. She also saw her siblings lose their jobs under the Obama administration and blames him for their work in the electronics industry being outsourced to other countries.

— Madeline Ackley

8 p.m.: Ducey says all votes will be counted

Gov. Doug Ducey reassured voters that all votes are and will be counted as protesters gathered outside a Maricopa County election office for a second night.

He last commented on the election process on Wednesday morning, urging patience and stressing that all votes will be counted.

On Twitter on Thursday night, Ducey encouraged news organizations and pundits not to declare a winner in the presidential contest while elections officials continued their work. He thanked voters for their patience.

“We’ve seen dramatic changes to races up and down the ballot since Tuesday night, including for President. All of this underlines the importance of not jumping to conclusions in the state of Arizona until there’s a final outcome in all counties,” he wrote on Twitter.

“In Arizona, we count votes received up until Election Day. That’s it. No judges have intervened and no last-minute changes have been enacted. We’re following established Arizona election law to the letter.”

— Rachel Leingang

7:30 p.m.: Hundreds protest outside Maricopa County elections office

At least a couple of hundred people protested in a fenced “Free Speech Zone” outside the Maricopa County Tabulation and Election Center in downtown Phoenix.

People carried Trump and American flags and signs that said “stop the cheat” and “Biden got beat.” The group at times sang “Y.M.C.A.” and "The Star-Spangled Banner," prayed, chanted “count the votes,” and cheered after a drop of ballot results narrowed Biden’s lead in Arizona.

Some carried guns, and some criticized journalists covering the protest.

Among the crowd was Rep. Paul Gosar, extremist group AZ Patriots founder Jennifer Harrison and right-wing social-media personality Mike Cernovich, who traveled from California to be at the protest.

Candice Savino, of Peoria, said she believes voter fraud is occurring nationally.

“Right now, a lot of us are panicking, it hurts really bad because we honestly feel our way of life, as free Americans, our constitutional rights, are about to be infringed on,” she said.

Elections officials have assured voters that all ballots will be counted, and there is no evidence of voter fraud.

— Chelsea Curtis and Madeline Ackley

7:15 p.m.: Arizona attorney general says Sharpies didn't disenfranchise voters

The Arizona Attorney General's Office said Thursday it is satisfied that Maricopa County's choice of Sharpie markers for use at polling places did not disenfranchise voters.

Several Republican figures, such as American Conservative Union Chair Matt Schlapp, seized on questions about the markers Wednesday. But election officials have said repeatedly that using a felt tip pen on a ballot issued by Maricopa County would not ruin the ballot.

Attorney General Mark Brnovich jumped into the fray the day after voting ended, posting a letter to Maricopa County election officials on social media that asked several questions about Sharpies and voting.

The county responded at length on Thursday, even inviting the attorney general to watch a demonstration of the tabulating equipment himself.

Michael Catlett, a lawyer for the attorney general's office, defended the inquiry in a reply.

"While some have attempted to characterize those complaints as a product of a 'conspiracy theory,' it was necessary and appropriate for AGO to conduct some investigation, rather than simply brushing hundreds of Arizona voters off, and to obtain information from the elected officials actually tasked with tabulating votes," Catlett wrote.

The office said it would continue to follow up on complaints and concerns from individual voters, but considered the broader issue of Sharpies the letter asked about to be concluded.

"Based on correspondence and conversations with Maricopa County officials, we are now confident that the use of Sharpie markers did not result in disenfranchisement for Arizona voters. We appreciate the county’s prompt insight and assurances to address public concerns," Brnovich wrote on Twitter, attaching the letter, on Thursday night.

— Andrew Oxford

7 p.m.: Biden's lead in Arizona narrows

President Donald Trump further narrowed Democratic candidate Joe Biden’s lead in Arizona on Thursday night as Maricopa County posted more results.

The ballot drop came as Trump continued to gain ground throughout Thursday as counties around the state posted results that largely favored him over Biden.

Maricopa County has now reported the results from 1.86 millon ballots, according to the Maricopa County Elections Department.

More results are expected at 9 a.m. and 7 p.m. Friday, according to county elections officials.

7 p.m.: Prop 208 maintains lead

Proposition 208, which would raise taxes on the wealthy to fund education in Arizona, is still ahead after a new batch of Maricopa County results posted Thursday night.

7 p.m.: Schweikert extends lead

Incumbent David Schweikert extended his lead over Democrat Hiral Tipirneni in the District 6 U.S. House race after a new batch of results posted Thursday evening.

7 p.m.: Arizona Corporation Commission update

A Democrat and two Republicans held their leads in the six-way race for three seats on the Arizona Corporation Commission after a new batch of results posted Thursday evening.

The commission sets rates and policies for utilities, including how much renewable energy they use.

Democrat Anna Tovar along with Republicans Lea Márquez Peterson and Jim O'Connor held the top spots.

7 p.m.: Adel maintains lead over Gunnigle

Maricopa County Attorney Allister Adel continued her slight lead over Democratic challenger Julie Gunnigle in the Maricopa County attorney race after a new batch of results posted Thursday night.

6:15 p.m.: Biden's lead in Arizona narrows

As counties continued counting ballots, Democratic candidate Joe Biden’s lead in Arizona grew narrower.

President Donald Trump’s campaign got a boost on Thursday evening from the Democratic stronghold of Pima County. Election workers counted more than 28,000 early ballots and showed them breaking favorably for Trump.

Mark Evans, the spokesperson for Pima County, said 14,484 of the early votes counted Thursday were cast for Trump, while 13,045 early ballots counted on Thursday were cast for Biden. That’s a 1,400 net gain for Trump as he has narrowed Biden's lead statewide.

Evans said Pima County still has 9,000 remaining early ballots that need to be tabulated, as well as 18,000 provisional ballots.

The county recorder has begun the process of verifying those provisional ballots, he added.

Ballots from smaller counties came in batches over the course of the day, with votes in right-leaning counties breaking for the president.

Cochise, Yavapai, Mohave and Pinal counties all posted results batches that strongly favored Trump. Coconino County’s ballots posted Thursday slightly favored Biden. Ballots in Apache County strongly favored Biden.

A ballot drop is expected from Maricopa County, the state's most populous county with the most outstanding ballots, at 7 p.m. Thursday.

— Rafael Carranza and Rachel Leingang

6 p.m.: Sharpies go to court

The day after Arizona gained national attention for allegations that the use of Sharpies on ballots caused votes to go uncounted, Maricopa County elections officials were in court explaining to a judge that Sharpie use did not cause any issues with voting on Election Day.

Judge Margaret R. Mahoney in a scheduling hearing asked attorneys representing a voter and poll worker concerned about the use of Sharpies and attorneys representing county officials to discuss how quickly they could move forward with the case, considering the county is nearly finished processing ballots and counting votes.

Thomas Liddy, a county attorney, explained to the judge that Sharpies were fine to use to fill out ballots, and asked the judge to dismiss the case because "the voters have a right to know that the allegations flying around the Internet about Sharpies being dropped from black helicopters to cheat people out of their votes is fake. It's not true, but it's really scaring people. We need to resolve this issue once and for all.”

The Republican National Committee and Donald J. Trump for President, Inc. intervened in the court case against county officials, with elections attorney Kory Langhofer asking the judge to allow members of the public who were concerned about Sharpie use to watch the counting of ballots.

Liddy said that anyone can watch the counting of ballots on the county's website, but he didn't understand how that would help, since it's mostly early ballots being counted, not the ones that were already processed and counted in person on Election Day.

The judge did not make any decisions on the parties' requests in the case. Liddy said that he was interested in filing a motion to dismiss the case on behalf of the parties, and Alexander Kolodin, the attorney representing the county resident and poll worker, said that he wanted the case to go to a hearing soon.

The resident in the case, Laurie Aguilera, is claiming that, while voting in person at a vote center on Tuesday, the "ballot box failed to properly register her vote" after poll workers gave her a Sharpie to fill out her ballot, and then a poll worker who had consulted with the Maricopa County Recorder's Office refused to provide her a new ballot.

Joshua Banko, the poll worker in the case, is claiming he was working as an elections clerk at Paradise Valley Mall in Phoenix and most voters there experienced issues with the ballot tabulating machines all day that he assumed were because of the use of Sharpies.

— Jen Fifield

5:15 p.m.: Faith leaders denounce Wednesday protest as another begins

Two Arizona faith groups issued a statement on Thursday denouncing the more than 100 protesters — including members of the extremist group AZ Patriots — who showed up at the Maricopa County Tabulation and Election Center in Phoenix demanding they be allowed to oversee the vote-counting process.

Valley Interfaith Project and Arizona Interfaith Network released a joint statement saying they recognized frustrations at the prolonged ballot-counting process, but that threatening election officials was unacceptable.

“The unwarranted provocation, aided and abetted by fringe group extremists, is an affront to the democratic process,” the statement read. “The belligerent tone of the gathering clearly was intended to intimidate election officials and observers, creating an unsettled atmosphere and perhaps sanctioning future uprisings and potential violence.”

Though no skirmishes occurred between the Trump supporters and the Maricopa County Sheriff deputies who barred them from entering, several supporters were armed with guns. Right-wing extremist Mike Cernovich and Rep. Paul Gosar tweeted on Thursday asking people to protest outside the election center once again but leave the firearms at home.

“I know it’s your right in Arizona but I am against open carry and ask you not do that,” Cernovich said in a tweet. Gosar suggested on Twitter that people bring flags and bibles instead.

On Thursday, fencing was installed throughout part of the election center’s parking lot with the exterior being a designated “free speech zone.” Deputies allowed protesters to gather just before the steps leading to the building’s entrance on Wednesday evening.

— Perry Vandell

4:30 p.m.: When to expect the next rounds of ballot results

All those watching and waiting for Maricopa County's next rounds of ballot results should have an earlier night tonight.

The county expects to post a round of results at 7 p.m. Thursday and 9 a.m. Friday.

The move to push results in the morning instead of late at night comes after results were released at about 1 a.m. Thursday. Protesters supporting Trump gathered outside the county tabulation location last night while the ballot drops were awaited.

— Rachel Leingang

3:40 p.m.: County sets up free speech zone outside elections office

A free speech zone was set up Thursday outside the Maricopa County Tabulation and Election Center in downtown Phoenix in anticipation for additional protests.

The free speech zone would allow for people to protest while ensuring elections staff could “do their jobs and leave the building without the threat of intimidation,” said a tweet from the Maricopa County Elections Department.

“The eyes of the nation are on Maricopa County and its imperative that we balance the protection and well-being of our election workers and volunteers with the constitutional right of protesters who may wish to demonstrate outside the Elections Department,” the tweet said.

In coordination with the Maricopa County Sheriff’s Office, the zone was set up outside the center at 510 S. Third Avenue.

— Chelsea Curtis

3:20 p.m.: Are we just going to be known for Sharpies now?

One more thing about Sharpies: The website Sharpiegate.com now directs to a fundraising page for the Biden Victory Fund.

“DONATE TO DEFEAT TRUMP AND THE REPUBLICANS,” the website says.

“The latest polls show Joe Biden with a narrow lead over Donald Trump in key swing states that will decide who wins the White House. Joe and Democrats across the country are counting on your support to help them defeat Trump's allies up and down the ballot,” it says.

The website is run by ActBlue, a fundraising platform for Democratic candidates and progressive groups.

— Rachel Leingang

3 p.m.: Here's an update on all the latest Sharpie news

Arizona Attorney General Mark Brnovich said Thursday that he has no evidence to suggest there are any issues with the use of Sharpies at polling places, despite his office’s letter to Maricopa County elections officials questioning the practice.

"Do I think based on what I've heard now and what I've seen that maybe this was a little overblown? I think that I will, at this point, say that I will believe what the election officials have said verbally and take them at their word," Brnovich said in an interview with 12 News reporter Joe Dana, posted on Twitter.

The attorney general said he did not think anyone in Arizona was intentionally creating controversy or conspiracy.

"At the end of the day, think about this, if indeed there was an issue with Sharpies, I mean, I'm not a math whiz, but that would have affected both parties equally," he said.

Separately, the Maricopa County Elections Department responded on Thursday to Brnovich’s investigation of the use of Sharpies on ballots in the state, through a letter from the Maricopa County Attorney’s Office.

The letter answered the Attorney General’s questions regarding Sharpie use and rejected ballots, and explained that Sharpies are the pens that the ballot tabulation machine manufacturer recommends.

“Maricopa County’s ballots are designed in such a way that any “bleed through” caused by the ink cannot create false votes or cause a voter’s intended vote to be miscounted,” the letter states.

Poll workers gave out Sharpies at all 175 vote centers, and they“should have been used” been all voters, according to the letter. If something was wrong with a ballot causing it to not be read properly by the voting machine, the voting machine would alert the voter, and the voter was given the option of casting a new ballot.

The county is currently doing a post-election analysis to see how many of these “spoiled” ballots there were during this election, according to the letter, and will be completed prior to when votes are finalized.

— Jen Fifield and Andrew Oxford

2:30 p.m.: Trump campaign not suing over Arizona count

At a Trump campaign press conference on Thursday afternoon, Republican officials made clear they believe Arizona will be decided in Trump’s favor once all ballots are counted, delivering 11 electoral votes to Trump. But they didn’t have much to announce at the news briefing.

Votes counted in the past few ballot updates have trended in Trump’s favor, though it remains unclear if the president can make up the ground and catch up with Joe Biden in Arizona. The national map remains unsettled, with no candidate getting 270 electoral votes yet.

Trump campaign adviser David Bossie, the president of Citizens United, said he won’t be announcing any legal challenges in Arizona now. The campaign has filed lawsuits in other battleground states in the last 48 hours.

“There’s been no decisions on anything as of yet, but absolutely all options are on the table to protect every single legal vote that has been made in Arizona,” he said.

Bossie and other Republicans, including U.S. Rep. Debbie Lesko, former Arizona Treasurer Jeff DeWit and Arizona Republican Party Chairwoman Kelli Ward, told the crowd of Trump supporters gathered at the Arizona Republican Party headquarters on Thursday that the GOP would prove media organizations who called the race for Biden wrong.

“We have the team on the ground. We have the people. We have the momentum. We have the activist community that is not going to allow this race to be stolen from President Trump or from Republicans all the way down the ballot,” Ward said.

The news conference was brief and included little news. It served more to rally ardent Trump supporters who showed up.

After quick remarks from Lesko, Ward said anyone with questions about voter fraud could come up and talk to officials. A flock of people took her up on it.

— Maria Polletta and Rachel Leingang

2 p.m.: Secretary of State slams AG letter on Sharpies

The Arizona Secretary of State’s Office issued a scathing response on Thursday to Attorney General Mark Brnovich’s investigation of the use of Sharpies on ballots in the state.

In a letter to the Attorney General’s Office, State Elections Director Sambo Dul wrote that she hopes that the information her office provided would stop the attorney general from "perpetuating a conspiracy theory that undermines the hard work of Arizona's election administrators, poll workers and voters."

“The Secretary is committed to overseeing a fair election and dispelling misinformation that would make that job more difficult for state and county election officials,” Dul wrote. “She sincerely hopes that the Attorney General shares that same goal, and will join an ever-growing chorus of public officials and media sources that have correctly labeled what is now being referred to as 'SharpieGate' as the unfounded conspiracy theory that it is.”

Brnovich began investigating after his office heard concerns from voters that the use of Sharpies on ballots caused their votes not to count.

Election officials have reassured voters that it was OK to use Sharpies to fill out ballots.

"First, inherent in your questions is the false assumption that using Sharpies on a ballot causes ballots to be rejected, spoiled, or canceled," Dul wrote. "That is simply not true, as the Maricopa County Elections Department and the Maricopa County Board of Supervisors has publicly explained."

— Andrew Oxford

1:30 p.m.: Trump campaign calls Arizona press conference

The Trump campaign called a press conference in Arizona at 2 p.m. Thursday at Arizona Republican Party headquarters.

The press conference will feature U.S. Rep. Debbie Lesko, former Arizona Treasurer Jeff DeWit, Arizona Republican Party Chairwoman Kelli Ward David Bossie, the president of Citizens United.

— Rachel Leingang

1 p.m.: Trump supporters plan evening protest, county continues counting

Republican protesters concerned about their votes not being counted in Tuesday’s election made plans to meet up again at the Maricopa County Elections Department headquarters in downtown Phoenix on Thursday night.

Protesters gathered outside of the headquarters, where county workers are counting remaining early ballots, on Wednesday night, and outside of Phoenix City Hall on Thursday morning.

Meanwhile, Megan Gilbertson, a department spokesperson, said the protesting has not disturbed the continued counting of ballots. There were about 282,000 in Maricopa County, including 18,000 provisional votes, remaining as of Thursday morning and the county had an original goal of counting all ballots by Nov. 10.

Gilbertson said that the county has not seen a need to increase security at the elections department, considering the Sheriff’s Department has already been providing security at the headquarters since the election began.

The election’s department shares the building with the sheriff’s department, so law enforcement is always present at the building, she said.

Election staff that helps with ballot processing and counting is shuttled to and from the building, so there are not concerns about their safety as they come and go from the building, Gilbertson said.

County elections officials had a fence installed around headquarters on Thursday morning in preparation for the protests.

Protesters began gathering this week after concerns that the use of Sharpies on Arizona ballots made it so votes were not counted properly. County elections officials continued to reassure voters that Sharpies were fine to use and the county’s machines can read ballots filled out with Sharpies, even if the ink bleeds through the page.

— Jen Fifield

12:30 p.m.: What is ballot curing?

As votes continue to be counted in Arizona, the normal process of ballot "curing" was also underway as election officials attempt to reach voters with errors on their ballots.

When counties receive a ballot with a signature that does not match the voter’s signature on record, the county will attempt to contact the voter to confirm their ballot in a process called "curing."

Arizona law says voters whose mail-in ballot has a mismatched signature have five business days after Election Day to fix and submit their ballot. In Maricopa County, election officials aimed "to have 99% of all valid ballots counted and reported by the end of the cure period," listed as 5 p.m. Nov. 10, according to their plan.

Maricopa County Recorder Adrian Fontes during the 2018 election said in the process of verifying signatures, the county will attempt to contact the voter using the phone number and email on file with the voter’s registration.

He said the county will call multiple times, leave the voter a voicemail and send an email in an attempt to get in contact with the voter.

While county officials try to verify the signature on the green envelopes that contain a voter’s ballot, they occasionally come across an envelope with no signature at all.

Voters can check on the status of their ballot using the state elections site, my.arizona.vote.

— BrieAnna Frank and Julian Alberto Hernandez

11:45 a.m.: Sheriff’s candidate page shares petition asking for recount

Jerry Sheridan, the Republican candidate for Maricopa County sheriff, shared a White House petition on his Facebook account asking that there be a recount of ballots in Arizona. The petition says it was started Wednesday by someone who identifies as R.P.

It was signed by more than 144,000 people as of Thursday, the petition shows.

The petition says Arizona “was called too soon.” Election officials in the state are still counting ballots, and no count has been finalized.

Sheridan, who is behind incumbent Sheriff Paul Penzone in the latest vote count by 14 percentage points, also shared on his Facebook the debunked conspiracy theory that people who voted in person using Sharpie pens may have their ballots invalidated.

“I was unaware an administrator with access to my Campaign Facebook page posted this. It has since been removed because I do not have an opinion on this issue either way. I need more information,” Sheridan told The Republic in a written statement.

"I would disagree that it has been debunked however. Unless and until it has been determined by the Arizona Attorney General that the use of Sharpies did not interfere with the election process I will form no opinion on this issue either way. Thank you for bringing this to my attention.”

— Uriel Garcia

11:30 a.m.: Pro-Trump supporters rally in front of Phoenix City Hall

Several dozen people gathered in front of Phoenix City Hall on Thursday morning to support Donald Trump and demand that elections officials count all votes.

About 50 to 60 people and news media members were seen shortly before 11 a.m. in front of City Hall, at 200 W. Washington St.

A rally was planned for 6 p.m. in front of the Maricopa County Elections Department, where protesters gathered Wednesday night to demand that election workers keep counting votes.

10:45 a.m.: Pima County keeps counting, scraps plans for pause

Election officials in Arizona’s second most populous county scrapped plans on Thursday morning to put a pause on the tabulation of outstanding ballots and have since said they will continue counting 22,000 votes throughout the day. But it remained unclear whether they would finish counting them all by the end of Thursday, and the county still has an additional 23,000 ballots left to verify and tabulate.

Mark Evans, the spokesperson for Pima County, said the director for the county’s Elections Department had initially intended to pause the counting of ballots in order to finish the signature verification process for all outstanding early ballots and then count them on Friday morning.

“But clearly the urgency of this election and the role that Arizona is playing argued against that, and so the county administrator this morning asked the election director to continue counting today,” Evans said.

The process to count them would take some time, he added. The county recorder must first verify signatures on all early ballots. The elections department then has to remove the ballots from the envelopes, examine them for any issues, and prepare them to get counted.

The Pima County Elections Department has about 40 employees preparing the ballots to be tabulated and nine that are counting the ballots.

They have also been using machines to speed up the process.

“We will have ballots to count, whether it’s the entire 22,000 depends upon the speed of the election boards and whether they can get them all ready to be tabulated,” Evans said. “They will get some of them done, hopefully all of them.”

Pima County counted about 5400 votes on Wednesday and posted the results that afternoon. But there are still between 5,000-8,000 early ballots and 18,000 provisional ballots that still need to be verified and counted. Evans said the county will not begin processing and counting the provisional ballots until all early ballots are tabulated.

— Rafael Carranza

10:15 a.m.: Schweikert widens lead in 6th Congressional District

Rep. David Schweikert’s narrow lead over Democrat Hiral Tipirneni in the 6th Congressional District race widened a bit late Wednesday, giving him a nearly 2 percentage point lead in the closely watched race.

Schweikert, R-Ariz., trailed as the numbers from the early-voting period first came in, a period dominated by Democrats across the state.

He has erased that lead as the tally has moved to the last of the early votes and Election Day balloting, a period that went solidly to Republicans.

Unofficial results through late Wednesday showed Schweikert’s lead had grown to 6,400 votes.

Tipirneni was among the best-funded challengers in the country, but she is battling in a district where Republicans hold a 12-percentage point registration advantage.

Schweikert is seeking a sixth term in Washington after the House of Representatives reprimanded him this summer for violating 11 ethics rules.

— Ronald J. Hansen

9:30 a.m.: Democrats make gains in 2020

Arizona will have two Democratic senators for the first time since the 1950s.

Democrats were leading across Maricopa County in statehouse races and municipal government.

Democrats have made competitive races in Arizona where they didn't exist before.

But President Donald Trump’s campaign insists he could still come back to win the state.

Sen. Martha McSally, R-Ariz., has not conceded the special election race to finish the U.S. Senate term initially won by the late Sen. John McCain, R-Ariz. There are also two competitive congressional races where each party holds fragile leads.

— Ronald J. Hansen, Yvonne Wingett Sanchez and Jen Fifield

8:30 a.m.: Protests at elections center Wednesday night

Pro-Trump protesters gathered at the Arizona Capitol and Maricopa County elections center Wednesday night to demand that election workers keep counting votes.

Protesters began leaving the Maricopa County Tabulation and Election Center in downtown Phoenix after people sang “YMCA” at about 9:50 p.m. By 10:15 p.m., Maricopa County Sheriff’s Office deputies were escorting election workers and staffers to their vehicles.

Maricopa County Sheriff Paul Penzone said Thursday morning, in a statement, that his office was committed to community safety and protecting the democratic process. Deputies defended entryways to the elections office Wednesday night to ensure the safety of the staff.

"Our efforts will continue and expand to appropriately meet the capacity and dynamics of these potential engagements," Penzone said, in the statement.

"Peaceful activities will be respected and protected. Acts of violence, threatening behaviors or criminal damage of property will not be tolerated. We are unwavering in our efforts to promote public safety,” he said.

The Maricopa County Elections Department said in a statement that "Staff at the Maricopa County Elections Department will continue our job, which is to administer elections in the second largest voting jurisdiction in the country. We will release results again tonight as planned. We thank the Maricopa County Sheriff’s Office for doing their job, so we can do ours."

— Perry Vandell, Salma Reyes, Katelyn Keenehan and Kaila White

8 a.m.: Court hearing set in Sharpie lawsuit

A court ordered Maricopa County Recorder Adrian Fontes to appear Thursday afternoon for a hearing in a lawsuit arguing voters given a Sharpie to fill out their election ballots should be allowed to observe the counting of their ballots in person.

The lawsuit was filed amid false allegations that conservative voters were given felt-tipped pens to use to disqualify their ballots. These rumors were dispelled by election officials on Wednesday.

Lawyers sued Fontes on behalf of a woman claiming that when she attempted to vote using the felt-tipped pen provided at the poll, "the ballot box failed to properly register her vote causing a poll worker to cancel her ballot," according to court documents.

When she requested a new ballot, the lawsuit alleged, the poll workers refused after consulting the Recorder's Office.

"Upon information and belief, many other voters have experienced similar issues," the documents said.

Maricopa County Superior Court ordered both the plaintiff and Fontes appear virtually at 3:30 p.m. Thursday for a hearing to show cause, or to explain or prove claims the judge needs to make a decision.

— Emily Wilder

7:30 a.m.: Trump makes up ground on Biden

As Maricopa County released the results from 140,000 more ballots on Wednesday night and Thursday morning, President Donald Trump received almost the exact share he would need to charge back to win Arizona's 11 electoral votes and potentially reelection.

Trump won the batches of ballots from Maricopa County counted Wednesday and early Thursday by a roughly 57-40 margin over former Vice President Joe Biden.

Those votes — likely early ballots sent to the county on Monday and Tuesday — narrowed Biden's lead over Trump in Arizona to 68,000 votes, when his lead had been more than 90,000 votes earlier Wednesday.

Paul Bentz, a Republican pollster with the consulting firm HighGround, said Trump needs to win 57.6% of the 470,000 votes that The Arizona Republic estimates remain to be counted.

"That's almost exactly what he got in the first batch," Bentz said. "He could do it."

— Rob O'Dell

search_result.text:
(CNN Business) For weeks, the countless takes, tweets, and TikToks about actor Johnny Depp's defamation trial against Amber Heard have been inescapable. It was hard to ignore the fierce online embrace of Depp or the vitriol directed at Heard. It became clear that the trial wasn't just about which Hollywood actor was to be believed --— it was, in part, a proxy for a broader culture war over the "Me Too" movement.

On Wednesday, a jury of five men and two women dealt a victory to Depp in his defamation case against Heard, his ex-wife. Heard, for her part, prevailed in part of her counterclaim against Depp. Depp charged that Heard had falsely and maliciously accused him of domestic abuse, costing him millions in damages from lost acting jobs after an opinion piece attributed to Heard was published by The Washington Post in 2018. While the piece didn't name Depp directly, Heard described herself as a "public figure representing domestic abuse."

The verdict rapidly made its way across social media platforms, with some conservative pundits such as Ann Coulter and Meghan McCain declaring the death of #MeToo. (McCain's tweet, which read: "#MeToo is dead. Helluva job @ACLU" has since been deleted; the ACLU wrote a draft of the opinion piece and helped place it. Heard is an ambassador for the organization.)

Tarana Burke, who started the "Me Too" Movement years before it would become a viral hashtag, stressed in a statement Thursday that the movement is "very much alive."

Burke said people try to "kill" the hashtag "every few months" as a sport, but that "it means something to millions and millions of folks."

(CNN) Before he gave the order to kill Ayman al-Zawahiri, President Joe Biden wanted to intimately understand where the al Qaeda leader was hiding.

The US drone strike that killed Zawahiri on his balcony in downtown Kabul was the product of months of highly secret planning by Biden and a tight circle of his senior advisers. Among the preparations was a small-scale model of Zawahiri's safe house, constructed by intelligence officials and placed inside the White House Situation Room for Biden to examine as he debated his options.

For Biden, the opportunity to take out the world's most wanted terrorist, one of the masterminds of the September, 11, 2001, attacks, was fraught with the risk of accidentally killing civilians in the Afghan capital — just as a US drone strike did 11 months ago during the chaotic US military withdrawal from the country.

How al-Zawahiri met bin Laden and became the leader of al Qaeda

How al-Zawahiri met bin Laden and became the leader of al Qaeda 03:41

How al-Zawahiri met bin Laden and became the leader of al Qaeda

Details of the strike and its planning were disclosed by a senior administration official as Biden was preparing to announce the mission Monday.

Throughout the months-long effort to plan this weekend's strike, Biden repeatedly tasked his officials with ensuring civilians -- including members of Zawahiri's family -- weren't killed. None were, according to the White House.

Biden, who was isolating due to a Covid-19 infection during the final deliberations and authorization of the strike, emerged to proclaim success on a White House balcony Monday. It was a moment of victory for a President who has been besieged by domestic political troubles that stretch back to the deadly Afghanistan withdrawal a year ago.

"People around the world no longer need to fear the vicious and determined killer. The United States continues to demonstrate our resolve and our capacity to defend the American people against those who seek to do us harm," Biden said from the Blue Room Balcony of the White House.

The President was first briefed in April on US intelligence placing Zawahiri at a safe house in Kabul. American officials had been aware of a network supporting the terrorist leader in the Afghan capital for months, and had identified his wife, daughter and her children through multiple streams of intelligence.

The women utilized terrorist "tradecraft" that officials deemed designed to prevent anyone from following them to Zawahiri's location in a Kabul neighborhood. Zawahiri himself didn't leave the location after his arrival this year.

As the months wore on, US officials began to establish patterns at the house — including Zawahiri emerging periodically onto the home's balcony for sustained periods of time.

As officials continued to monitor his activities, an effort began in complete secret to analyze the building's construction and structure, with an eye toward developing an operation to take out the world's No. 1 terrorist target without compromising the building's structural integrity.

At top of mind for Biden and members of his team was avoiding civilian deaths, including the members of Zawahiri's family who were living in the building. Independent analysts from across the government were involved in identifying the other occupants of the house.

That the building was located in downtown Kabul presented its own challenges.

Surrounded by a residential neighborhood, officials were mindful their planning and information needed to be "rock solid" before presenting any options to Biden. And they were highly wary of leaks -- only a "very small and select group" at a scattering of key agencies were informed of the plans being laid.

Biden was also concerned about how it might affect US efforts to secure the return of Mark Frerichs, an American citizen taken hostage in Afghanistan more than two years ago. A senior administration official said Biden pressed his team to mitigate risks to those efforts, along with the ongoing attempts to relocate Afghans who helped the US during the war.

"Going forward with the Taliban, we will continue to hold them accountable for their actions. And we have made clear to them in the intervening days that we also expect them to take no action that would harm Mark Frerichs, as we were involved in the effort to secure his release after his long detention and captivity," the official said.
